notes: On 15 November 2023, approximately 150 demonstrators, including members of If Not Now, Jewish Voice for Peace, Democratic Socialists of America, rabbis, and Israeli-Americans, demonstrated outside of the Democratic National Committee in Washington DC - Southeast (District of Columbia) to demand that Democrats support a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas. Capitol Police came to disperse the demonstration, which they claimed was illegal and violent. Demonstrators blocked the doors of the headquarters while a fundraiser was taking place inside. Police pulled demonstrators roughly away from the doors of the headquarters, but demonstrators locked arms and resisted. At least one demonstrator was pulled by police and fell down a small flight of stairs. Police roughly pushed dozens of demonstrators to move them away from the doors. They also deployed pepper spray on demonstrators, who claimed that over 90 injuries took place as a result. Police claimed that six officers sustained injuries after being pepper sprayed and punched, and that some demonstrators threw objects, including a bike rack, at the police. Police arrested one demonstrator for assaulting an officer. Demonstrators said that they had remained peaceful and that police had not warned them before using violence. Videos of the demonstration did not appear to show any demonstrators attacking police. The demonstration took place in the wake of renewed fighting between Israel and Hamas.

notes: On 14 November 2023, between tens and hundreds of thousands of pro-Israeli protesters, including Jewish people, Israeli-Americans, Israeli citizens, Protestant and Catholic Christians, and students, gathered in Washington DC - National Mall (District of Columbia) to support Israel, call for the release of the Israeli hostages taken by Hamas, and stand against antisemitism. The March for Israel was organized by the Jewish Federation of Greater Washington and Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations. Protesters also chanted to bring the hostages home, let Israel live, and against a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas. Protesters pointed to Israel's 'democracy,' 'Western values,' and 'support of the LGBTQ+ community' in contrast to Hamas, which they condemned. Many members of Congress were at the event: Mike Johnson (R), Joni Ernst (R), Chuck Schumer (D), Ritchie Torres (D), John Fetterman (D), Bob Casey (D), Richard Blumenthal (D), Grace Meng (D), Ruben Gallego (D), Eric Sorensen (D), Steny Hoyer (D), Norma Torres (D), Jerrod Nadler (D), Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D), Jim Hines (D), Joe Vogel (D) and former Arizona State Rep Daniel Hernandez (D). A small counter-demonstration was held by Hasidic Jewish men who held signs saying that 'authentic rabbis are opposed to Israel.' The demonstrations took place in the wake of renewed fighting between Israel and Hamas.

notes: On 22 May 2023, a man drove a U-Haul truck into the security barriers at Lafayette Square in Washington DC - National Mall (District of Columbia). After the initial impact, the man reversed and drove into the barriers again after which he exited the car holding a Nazi swastika flag. The man is alleged by federal prosecutors to have desired to 'overthrow the government and replace it with an authoritarian regime fueled by Nazi ideology,' including by killing President Joe Biden. He did not have any weapons in his possession at the time, but had a book that detailed plans to harm people as well as a 'speech' that they argue he intended to give if he overthrew the government. The perpetrator admitted that he had been planning the attack for six months and admired the Nazis according to court records. Prosecutors allege that he also planned additional attacks, the details of which were not made public. The man is currently charged with 'threatening to kill, kidnap or inflict harm on the president, vice president or a family member.'

notes: On 18 March 2023, a US Park Police officer shot and killed a Black teen inside a car at 34th and Baker St NE in Washington DC - Northeast (District of Columbia). In released body cam footage, officers found a running vehicle with the teen asleep in the driver's seat. They discovered that the car was stolen after running its tags. The officers decided to cut open plastic serving as a rear passenger's side window in order to restrain the teen from both directions. When officers attempted to enter the car from both sides and physically detain the teen, a brief scuffle ensued, after which the teen was able to drive away. One police officer standing at the driver's side door fell down, while another was left in the back of the vehicle. The officer in the car then instructed the teen to stop the car and let him out - after roughly ten additional seconds passed, the officer yelled 'Stop! Stop or I'll shoot!' and then fired 'almost immediately,' hitting the teen in the back and killing him. The vehicle then crashed into a house. The shooting is currently under federal investigation.

source: Facebook; News2Share; Twitter; Washington Times; World Socialist Web Site; WUSA9
notes: On 19 February 2023, several hundred to 1000 people rallied near the Lincoln Memorial in Washington DC - National Mall (District of Columbia) as part of the 'Rage Against the War Machine' to demonstrate against the war in Ukraine and to call for peace. Some demonstrators also demonstrated against US support for Ukraine, while others supported the Russian invasion. Those present included people with Russian flags, Imperial Russia flags, and Soviet flags, and 'Z' symbols, members of Veterans for Peace, members of CodePink, and supporters of the Partido da Causa Operaria (PCO). Some demonstrators held a sign reading 'Ukraine out of Donbass, NATO out of business.' Speakers at the event included Chris Hedges, former US Representative Ron Paul, former US Representative Tulsi Gabbard, former US Representative Dennis Kucinich, stand-up comedian Jimmy Dore, former Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein, a journalist for Sputnik, and members of the GrayzoneNews media. One of the organizers of the Unite the Right rally was also present with members of his recently-established group Patriot Socialist Front. He was wearing a shirt depicting Oswald Mosley, who led the British Union of Fascists in the 1930s. Members of the Oath Keepers were also present. An unknown number of Ukrainians gathered with Ukrainian flags to counter-demonstrate and to show support for Ukraine amid the invasion. Some counter-demonstrators rallied in nearby Lafayette Square, where they also called for the release of former Georgian president Mikheil Saakashvili to a foreign hospital. Members of the greater Georgian and Ukrainian communities were present. After the 'Rage Against the War Machine' rally, protesters marched to the White House, where the two groups yelled at one another.

actor1: Police Forces of the United States (2021-2025)
actor2: Civilians (United States)
notes: On 10 February 2023, an officer approached a car in Anacostia in Washington DC - Southeast (District of Columbia) after he saw a man entering the car 'abruptly.' The officer ordered the man to get out of the car to which the man replied that he hadn't done anything and would not be exiting the car. The officer then grabbed the man by the jacket to pull him out of the vehicle. As the man attempted to twist away from the officer, the officer shot him in the 'mid-section.' The officer had been investigating a call from a woman about being attacked by a male assailant and believed the man fit the description given by the woman despite basing it on an article of clothing which the woman claimed she did not include in her description. Police later acknowledged that the man was not the person they were searching for, but claimed that he had cocaine and crack cocaine in his possession. The victim sustained serious but non-life threatening injuries.

Members of Shutdown DC and Extinction Rebellion DC participated in the protest. Cox Enterprises was targeted due to its ownership of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution newspaper and Wells Fargo was targeted due to its funding of the project.

Some also claimed that former President Donald J. Trump is still the President of the United States. Several Trump supporters held a 'Trump Won' flag before going from the east side of the Capitol to the west side. Ashli Babbitt's mother was arrested by capitol police after she refused to move from the road to the sidewalk. Once at the west side, demonstrators hung a banner that read 'Murdered by Capitol Police' and displayed images of people who died during the 6 January riots. Nearby, counter-demonstrators called for justice for the 6 January riots and rallied in support of democracy. Notable figures such as Martin Luther King III and US Representative John Sarbanes (D) were among those present.

notes: On 24 June 2022, several thousand people protested outside of the Supreme Court in Washington DC - National Mall (District of Columbia) in support of abortion rights and against the Supreme Court's decision in Dobbs v. Jackson which overturned Roe v. Wade. Members of Rise Up 4 Abortion Rights, Americans United, and the Party for Socialism and Liberation, as well as at least 150 Democratic lawmakers, including Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D), Rep. Maxine Waters (D), Rep. Al Green (D), Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D), and Rep. Mondaire Jones (D), participated in the protest. Maryland Congressional candidate McKayla Wilkes and members of Sister Song, Freedom Fighters DC, Codepink and ShutDown DC also participated in the protest later which was organized by Harriet's Dreams (a Black organization). A crowd of counter-protesters were also present in opposition to abortion and in support of the Supreme Court's decision. The counter-protesters were members of Students for Life, Concerned Women of America, Progressive Anti-Abortion Uprising, The Purple Sash Revolution, and Survivors of the Abortion Holocaust. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R) and Rep. Bob Good (R) briefly joined the counter-protesters. A few hundred pro-abortion protesters continued demonstrating into the night after the anti-abortion protesters had dispersed, and eventually were joined by protesters in black bloc from the group Bite Back.

notes: On 11 June 2022, from thousands to 40,000 people demonstrated in Washington DC - National Mall (District of Columbia) to call for the enactment of gun control legislation and an end to gun violence. During the protest, a man threw an object into the crowd, which the man reported was a handheld speaker, and yelled which caused protesters to run in fear. The man was detained by the US Park Police and released with a citation, but was later charged with disorderly conduct by creating fear and disrupting a gathering. The panic caused by the man led six rallygoers to be injured. Representative Cori Bush (D), DC Mayor Muriel Bowser (D), DC Youth Mayor Addison Rose, and shooting survivors, as well as representatives of the National Education Association, Voice Buffalo (an interfaith social justice organization), Live Free USA (an interfaith organization), Faith in Action, National Nurses United, Fund Peace (a Black-led gun violence organization), and American Federation of Teachers participated in the event. The protest was part of the nationwide 'March for Our Lives' movement.

notes: On 17 May 2022, roughly 1500 people rallied near the U.S. Capitol in Washington DC - National Mall (District of Columbia) as part of the 'Jewish Rally for Abortion Justice' in support of abortion rights and against a leaked Supreme Court draft opinion which would overturn Roe v. Wade. Students, Senator Richard Blumenthal (D), Representative Carolyn Maloney (D), Representative Judy Chu (D), Maryland State Representative Kirill Reznik (D), as well as representatives from We Testify, Hadassah, National Asian Pacific American Women's Forum, Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice, Reconstructionist Rabbinical College, Jane Collective, MomsRising, National Women's Law Center, Keshet (an LGBTQ+ Jewish organization), Interfaith Alliance, Envision Justice, and the Anti-Defamation League attended the protest which was organized by the National Council of Jewish Women. They were joined by a handful of counter-protesters who protested in opposition to abortion rights and in support of the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion. These protesters were from the Jewish Pro-Life Foundation. Later in the day, about 150 people demonstrated in front of the Supreme Court in opposition to abortion rights and in support of the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion. An Evangelical Christian leader, several Christian religious leaders, Representative Lauren Boebert (R), Representative Marjory Taylor Greene (R), and members of Purple Sash Revolution participated in the protest. The protests were some of many nationwide sparked by a leaked draft decision of the Supreme Court on Dobbs v. Jackson which would overturn Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court case which protected the right to abortion.

actor2: Protesters (United States)
notes: On 4 May 2022, an unreported number of 'pro-life' protesters rallied outside of the Washington Surgi Clinic in Washington DC - Northwest (District of Columbia) to call for justice for five 'aborted late-term babies' which they obtained and say were aborted at this clinic and to call for someone to inform on the doctor who performs abortions there. The rally was organized by Progressive Anti-Abortion Uprising. Members of the group entered the clinic to distribute flyers advertising their award for information to the staff, and the police allowed them to leave without incident. Counter-protesters assembled across the street from them in opposition to their rally and in support of abortion and upholding Roe V. Wade. Some of the counter-protesters were students.

actor2: Civilians (United States)
notes: On 22 April 2022, a lone gunman opened fire in in Washington DC - Northwest (District of Columbia) with the intention of killing anyone around. Using a 'sniper-type setup,' the perpetrator injured four people while shooting dozens of rounds. Nearby, Edmund Burke School and the University of the District of Columbia as a security precaution. The gunman posted livestreams of the shooting to 4chan and expressed anti-Black sentiment online. The gunman killed himself later in the evening. It is unclear if there was a link between the shooting and Burke School.

Other: On 22 April 2022, a man set himself on fire outside the Supreme Court in Washington DC - National Mall (District of Columbia), leading to his death. This coincided with Earth Day, and some evidence indicates that the act may have been a form of protest against climate change. Police extinguished the fire, no other individuals were harmed, and the grounds surrounding the Supreme Court were temporarily closed pending investigation.

notes: Other: On 4 January 2022, campus operations were disrupted at Howard University, which is an HBCU in Washington DC - Northwest (District of Columbia), after receiving bomb threats. The threats were investigated, and no bombs were found. At least nine HBCUs received threats on this day, which may be connected to similar threats made towards HBCUs on 31 January 2022 and 1 February 2022.
